SonarQube Cloud integrates seamlessly into your GitHub workflow and provides clear guidance for resolving any code quality and security issues detected. The majority of popular languages can be analyzed automatically; no configuration is required!

With [SonarQube Cloud](https://sonarcloud.io/github), you get:

-   Fast, precise static analysis and feedback on your code
    
-   Support for popular languages, frameworks, and IaC tools
    
-   Free analysis for open-source projects and private projects up to max 50k LoC
    
-   Automatic analysis of pull requests and branches with results reported inline
    
-   IDE Support with [SonarQube for IDE](https://www.sonarsource.com/products/sonarlint/) integration
    
-   Quality Gate (added as a GitHub check) acting at two different levels - first, preventing you from merging pull requests that contain issues - and later, helping you to release only clean, safe code
    
-   Sign up for SonarQube free tier and begin scanning your private and public repositories

The answer is Continuous Query, it has built-in resiliency, batching, exactly-once delivery guarantee.

Events are better suited for things like observability and diagnostics.

> The answer is Continuous Query, it has built-in resiliency, batching, exactly-once delivery guarantee.
> 
> Events are better suited for things like observability and diagnostics.

Thank you for your response @ptupitsyn.
Could you please share the code? A minimal working reproducer would be ideal.

2.14.0-arm64 does not work with custom host port. Ignite client is able to discover the node but when simple "hello word" compute is done, it throws "message failed for node id", whereas simply changing the host port mapping from 47502:47500 to 47500:47500. On the emded client side I tried using both MultiCast IP finder and VImipfinder with the right ports, but it just don't work. Suspecting it is image issue.

SonarQube Cloud integrates seamlessly into your GitHub workflow and provides clear guidance for resolving any code quality and security issues detected. The majority of popular languages can be analyzed automatically; no configuration is required!

With [SonarQube Cloud](https://sonarcloud.io/github), you get:

-   Fast, precise static analysis and feedback on your code
    
-   Support for popular languages, frameworks, and IaC tools
    
-   Free analysis for open-source projects and private projects up to max 50k LoC
    
-   Automatic analysis of pull requests and branches with results reported inline
    
-   IDE Support with [SonarQube for IDE](https://www.sonarsource.com/products/sonarlint/) integration
    
-   Quality Gate (added as a GitHub check) acting at two different levels - first, preventing you from merging pull requests that contain issues - and later, helping you to release only clean, safe code

A [GitHub Action](https://github.com/marketplace/actions/sonarcloud-scan) is available in the marketplace to make it easy for you (for projects where automatic analysis isn't available). SonarQube Cloud also integrates smoothly with Jenkins, CircleCI, TravisCI, CirrusCI, and many other tools.

A free tier is available that allows you to explore the benefits of SonarQube Cloud using your public and private repositories. body: Hi @ptupitsyn - Any update on this please?
Hi - Any suggestions or comments on this please?
Hi - Any suggestions or feedback on this please?

Looks like the `ID` is both the cache key, and a part of cache value (`Employees.id`) field.

* When you do `cache.put`, you duplicate the ID in two places
* When you insert via SQL, the ID only goes to the key part

To see how this works internally, try [Binary Mode](https://ignite.apache.org/docs/latest/key-value-api/binary-objects) - inspect the resulting object fields in both cases.

I recommend removing `Employees.id` field to avoid confusion. The id is already in the cache key.

Not sure about the problem here, but a general recommendation is to use Continuous Query instead of Events to track data updates

https://ignite.apache.org/docs/latest/key-value-api/continuous-queries

body:
Hi @liupan664021 ,

The main issue with the current MVCC implementation is that it is based on using a single node (the coordinator node of the cluster) for transaction ordering and 2PC protocol for distributed commits. IMHO, this approach is slow and is not scalable by design.

Also, It seems that there are not enough contributors/maintainers willing to support, develop, and improve the feature.

You can find additional details here:
 - [Mark MVCC with @IgniteExperimental](https://lists.apache.org/thread/5jf03fw2p0w4wg614vg2nvsbzz3ct20g)
 - [Removing MVCC public API](https://lists.apache.org/thread/nbsb21x514jbqph7on24spq6d8vpd33k)

Thanks,
S.

body:
1. There is no need to pass txId to server/to client. JDBC client can only use one transaction per session, so map of transactions redundant too, one reference to current transaction is enough. Old activeTx flag can be reused again, instead of deprecation to inform client about started transaction.
2. In the current implementation 3 request is required to perform query with auto commit (instead of 1 query in the previous implementation). We can reduce requests count. We already pass "autoCommit" flag with the message, so at least we can commit transaction on server side without additional endTxRequest. Also we can start transaction without startTxRequest for queryes with autoCommit, but in this case we should know tx parameters (for example pass it with handshake message and store in client context on server side)
3. Enabling TX_AWARE_QUERIES on server side will automatically break queries on atomic caches. So, I think, default isolation level should be TRANSACTION_NONE. For transactional caches with the new option you still need to add `commit`, so code for transactional caches will be rewritten in any case, so user also can add required isolation level too. But for atomic caches - it's working code, with no problems in current implementation, and it's not good to force user to rewrite working code. Also, problems with atomic caches will fire at new, unpredictional places, whenever problems with transactions are already known to user and it's better to rewrite code at known places.

```java
package org.example;

import org.apache.ignite.Ignition;
import org.apache.ignite.configuration.IgniteConfiguration;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        IgniteConfiguration igniteConfiguration = new IgniteConfiguration();
        igniteConfiguration.setWorkDirectory(System.getProperty("user.home") + "/w/tests/ignite-work");

        Ignition.start(igniteConfiguration);
    }
}
```
